data.title: Camera captures night sky spiral after SpaceX rocket launch
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: A camera atop Hawaii's tallest mountain has captured what looks like a spiral swirling through the night sky.

data.author: John Schwartz
data.title: Bill McKibben and Xiye Bastida, Two Climate Activists 40 Years Apart in Age, on the Movement’s Future
data.source: The New York Times
data.description: Bill McKibben published his first book over 20 years before Xiye Bastida was born. But as climate leaders, they agree that “for an activist to have hope is the most important thing.”

data.author: Natasha Frost
data.title: New Zealand’s Largest City Grapples With Aftermath of Devastating Floods
data.source: The New York Times
data.description: At least two people were killed in the flooding in Auckland that forced hundreds of people from their homes and shut down the city’s airport, which was submerged.

data.author: Clifford Krauss
data.title: China’s Oil and Gas Use Fell in 2022 for First Time in Decades
data.source: The New York Times
data.description: Pandemic lockdowns curbed Chinese energy demand, but the International Energy Agency expects a rebound this year.

data.title: A new way to identify stresses in complex fluids
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Fluid dynamics researchers use many techniques to study turbulent flows like ocean currents, or the swirling atmosphere of other planets. Arezoo Adrekani's team has discovered that a mathematical construct used in these fields provides valuable information about stress in complex flow geometries.

data.title: ChatGPT: Study shows AI can produce academic papers good enough for journals—just as some ban it
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Some of the world's biggest academic journal publishers have banned or curbed their authors from using the advanced chatbot, ChatGPT. Because the bot uses information from the internet to produce highly readable answers to questions, the publishers are worried that inaccurate or plagiarized work could enter the pages of academic literature.

data.title: First observation of de Broglie-Mackinnon wave packets achieved by exploiting loophole in 1980s theorem
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: University of Central Florida College of Optics and Photonics researchers achieved the first observation of de Broglie-Mackinnon wave packets by exploiting a loophole in a 1980s-era laser physics theorem.

data.title: Wie Ekel überwunden werden kann
data.source: ORF.at Science
data.description: Die EU hat diese Woche Hausgrillen als Lebensmittel zugelassen: als Ganzes oder in Form von Pulver, etwa in Schokolade und Wurst. Wie der Ekel vor Insekten, der bei vielen tief sitzt, überwunden werden kann, erklärt ein Lebensmittelwissenschaftler.

data.title: European farms mix things up to guard against food-supply shocks
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Greater diversification could help agriculture withstand climate, economic and geopolitical crises.

data.title: Growing borrowing costs offset easing inflation, finds consumer survey
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Consumer sentiment lifted for the second straight month in January, rising 9% above December but remaining about 3% below a year ago, according to the University of Michigan Surveys of Consumers.

data.title: UV lamps used for disinfection may impair indoor air quality
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Using ultraviolet germicidal radiation (UVGI) to disinfect indoor spaces is a demonstrably effective way of deactivating various pathogens (including the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus). It deactivates bacteria and viruses by exposing them to high-energy UV radiation through the use of UV lamps.

data.title: Newly-named species of tree-dwelling snakes threatened by mining
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Five new tree-dwelling snake species were discovered in the jungles of Ecuador, Colombia, and Panama. Conservationists Leonardo DiCaprio, Brian Sheth, Re:wild, and Nature and Culture International chose the names for three of them in honor of loved ones while raising awareness about the issue of rainforest destruction at the hands of open-pit mining operations. The research was conducted by Ecuadorian biologist Alejandro Arteaga and Panamanian biologist Abel Batista.

data.title: Instrument on JWST has gone offline
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: The JWST is having a problem. One of its instruments, the Near Infrared Imager and Slitless Spectrograph (NIRISS), has gone offline. The NIRISS performs spectroscopy on exoplanet atmospheres, among other things.

data.title: Volcano-like rupture could have caused magnetar slowdown
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: On Oct. 5, 2020, the rapidly rotating corpse of a long-dead star about 30,000 light years from Earth changed speeds. In a cosmic instant, its spinning slowed. And a few days later, it abruptly started emitting radio waves.

data.title: Movements in proteins reveal information about antibiotic resistance spreading
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Researchers at Umeå University have discovered how a certain type of protein moves for DNA to be copied. The discovery could have implications for understanding how antibiotic resistance genes spread between bacteria.

data.title: Hubble views bright variable star V 372 Orionis and a smaller companion star
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: The bright variable star V 372 Orionis takes center stage in this image from the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, which has also captured a smaller companion star in the upper left of this image. Both stars lie in the Orion Nebula, a colossal region of star formation roughly 1,450 light-years from Earth.

data.title: Research reveals how redlining grades influenced later life expectancy
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Research from Washington University in St. Louis exposes the deadly legacy of redlining, the 1930s-era New Deal practice that graded neighborhoods by financial risk and solidified the notion that an area's property value was proportional to its racial composition.

data.title: Perseverance takes a selfie to show off some of its samples
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: One of the main jobs for the Perseverance Mars rover past few weeks has been collecting carefully selected samples of Mars rock and soil. These samples have been placed and sealed in special sample tubes and left in well-identified places so that a future sample return mission can collect them and bring the Martian samples back to Earth.

data.title: Four possible consequences of El Niño returning in 2023
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Every two to seven years, the equatorial Pacific Ocean gets up to 3°C warmer (what we know as an El Niño event) or colder (La Niña) than usual, triggering a cascade of effects felt around the world. This cycle is called the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) because every El Niño is naturally followed by a La Niña and vice versa, with some months of neutral conditions in between events. The change in sea surface temperature associated with ENSO events might seem marginal, but it is more than enough to disrupt weather patterns globally and even the large-scale circulation of air in the...

data.title: It'll take 150 years to map Africa's biodiversity at the current rate, say researchers
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Africa's biomes extend from mangroves to deserts, from Mediterranean to tropical forests, from temperate to sub-tropical and montane grasslands and savannas, and even to ice-capped mountains.

data.title: Restoring land for livelihoods can have ecological benefits, study suggests
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Small-scale restoration efforts that aim to help meet livelihood needs have the potential to contribute to ecological goals in the central Indian landscape, according to a new study published in Restoration Ecology.

data.title: Machine learning approach may aid water conservation push in the Colorado River basin
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: The Colorado River basin, which supplies water to 40 million people in the Western United States, is threatened by historic drought, a changing climate and water demands from growing cities. One potential response involves encouraging individuals to conserve water, and a new study may help identify those most likely to change their behaviors to contribute, according to scientists.

data.title: New model effectively predicts consumers' retail shopping mobility during a pandemic
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: COVID-19 forced people to contend with travel bans, stay-at-home orders and closure of nonessential businesses. A new study in the Journal of Business Research reveals how this significant event affected consumer mobility and shopping habits. And the results are hardly what one might predict.

data.title: Rosy finches are Colorado's high-alpine specialists, and researchers want to know why
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: Mountaineers who venture high into the Colorado Rockies have likely spotted medium-sized, brown-and-pink birds rummaging around on snow patches for insects and seeds. These high-elevation specialists are rosy finches, a type of bird that's evolved to survive in some of the most rugged places in North America.

data.title: Development of machine vision system capable of locating king flowers on apple trees
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
data.description: A machine vision system capable of locating and identifying apple king flowers within clusters of blossoms on trees in orchards was devised by Penn State researchers—a critical early step in the development of a robotic pollination system—in a first-of-its-kind study.
